column4: I try it again: I'm trying to sort out the source of my problem that smbfs mounts are quicker than cifs-mounts.. on the way i found that mii-tool and ethtool don't say the same (as i understand it)
what is your question?

ethtool and mii-tool use different interface to the kernel. ethtool = more modern (netlink), mii-tool = obsolete. depending on NIC drivers, one or other will work, ethtool being the more implemented one nowadays.
ok, so it could be possible, that mii-tool doesn't recognise a 1gb-ethernet ? it says that it negociated on 100-FullDuplex while ethtool says "speed: 1000Mb/s"
yes
if ethtool works, use it. forget about mii-tool.
ok thanks
do you know causes for a different speed between smbfs and cifs mounts?
differernt protocols more or less. smbfs uses NetBIOS over TCP/IP. CIFS uses SMB directly.
also different negotiation and all kinds of other stuff.
cifs mounts quickly here though. you might check your network traffic to debug
ciizarro: yeah, the mounting itself is no problem
but the transfers.. other way round, if i get a file to a windows -machine (working on it) it's very quick. so i guess the problem must be cifs..?
you didn't mention anything about transfers being slow. only mounts.
there is a bug in win xp >= TCP/IP stack in window scaling option negotation, you might be hitting that
sorry, i meant the transfers from these mounts.. the mounting itself goes well
what do you mean by "slow" then?
i'm not able to watch a movie within a cifs-mounted directory, but with smbfs it works without freezing every five secs
that's slow :)
so basically: a cifs-mounted directory is much slower than a smbfs-mounted directory.. and i don't have any clue where to look for the problem
quite busy now, but I'd start with google if I was you. something like "cifs much slower than smbfs when transffering data to windows from linux".
if i hadn't done that, i wouldnt be here :D
